Four Star Oil & Gas
Hatters Pond Gas Plant
Risk Management Plan

Executive Summary

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

Hatters Pond Gas Plant, a Four Star Oil & Gas property, has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our efforts in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes. Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, facility personnel will evaluate the situation, take actions within the capabilities of the facility, and/or notify the necessary outside agencies.


DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Hatters Pond Gas Plant, located in Creola, Alabama, U.S.A., operates a variety of processes to produce Condensate, Propane, Butane and Residue gas. Hatters Pond Gas Plant has regulated flammables, including:
A?    Iso-butane
A?    Normal Butane
A?    Ethane
A?    Methane
A?    Iso-Pentane
A?    Normal Pentane
A?    Propane


EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION 

Employees are consulted with on developing process hazard analyses, investigating incidents, writing operating procedures, and developing different aspects of PSM/RMP. Every employee has access to documentation and files included in PSM/RMP. It is the responsibility of every employee at the plant to comply with the aspects of PSM/RMP. The document entitled "Employee Participation" explains this section of PSM/RMP in greater detail.


PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION (PSI)

According to the PSM/RMP standard, there are three main aspects of Process Safety Information required to properly inform employees/public of the potential hazards of processes involving potentially hazardous chemicals.  They are the following:


Potential hazards of chemicals in process:

Information concerning the chemicals in the process is included in Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS).  Th

ey include information on the toxicity, permissible exposure limits, physical data, reactivity, corrosivity, thermal and chemical stability of the produced/processed materials and chemicals used in the plant. The potential hazards of different chemicals being mixed are covered under this subsection. Also covered are a worst case scenario and an alternate scenario, which could affect off site receptors.



Technology of process:

The technology of the process refers to descriptions of processes at the plant, maximum intended inventories, inventory calculations and safe upper and lower limits on temperatures, pressures, flow rates, and compositions.  Included in this subsection is the plant Process Flow Diagram (PFD).

Equipment in process:

Required information about equipment used in the plant includes: materials of construction, piping & instrumentation diagrams (P&ID's), electrical classifications, relief systems, and safety systems.  The design, maintenance, inspection, testing and operation of equipment is documented.


PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS

The Hatters Pond Gas Plant has a comprehensive program to ensure that hazards associated with the process are identified and controlled.  This program systematically examines the process to identify hazards and ensure adequate controls are in place to manage the identified hazards.

The Process Hazard Analysis requirement is met by the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) Studies conducted at the plant.


OPERATING PROCEDURES  

The Hatters Pond Gas Plant personnel use various PHA processes including the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) analysis and Check List techniques to perform these evaluations. The analyses are conducted using a team of personnel who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise. This team identifies and evaluates process hazards as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures.  Approved mitigation options in response to PHA team findings are initiated and tracked until c

ompletion. The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.


The operating procedures provide clear and thorough step-by-step instructions on operating various sections of the plant.  Operating limits and health considerations of the different processes, which are covered in Process Safety Information, are also requirements of operating procedures.  Step by step procedures for safe work practices, such as lockout/tagout, confined space entry, etc. are also included in this section.


TRAINING 

Training is required for employees involved in operating a process.  Types of training include operating procedures, maintenance procedures, mechanical integrity testing procedures, safety and potential health hazards, emergency operations, and safe work practices.  After initial training, refresher training is required every three (3) years, or more often if necessary or requested.  Training documentation includes the employee who received training, the date of training, and testing to verify that the employee understood the training. 


CONTRACTORS  

The Hatters Pond Gas Plant uses contractors to supplement its work force during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. This section of PSM/RMP covers contractors working on or adjacent to a covered process.  Both Plant personnel and the contractor have responsibilities under this section.  The PlantA?s responsibilities include:

    A?    Evaluating contract employer's safety performance and programs
    A?    Informing contract employer of potential hazards related to the work
    A?    Explaining Chevron U.S.A.s emergency action plan
    A?    Controlling contract employers entrance and exit to and from the plant
    A?    Periodically evaluating contractor's safety performance and maintaining an injury and illness log of contractor's work at the Plant

The contract employer's responsibilities include:

    A?    Training contract employees in safe work practices of his/her job
    A?    Instructing employees on potential hazar

ds of the job or process
    A?    Informing a Plant Representative of potential hazards in the contractor's work


PRE START-UP SAFETY REVIEW 

The Pre Start-Up Safety Review includes a review of operations and code requirements for new facilities, and modified facilities, which require a change in their Process Safety Information.  This section of PSM/RMP does not apply to Hatters Pond Gas Plant since it was in operation before the PSM/RMP regulation. New facilities or equipment added to the plant after the compliance dates is covered under "Management of Change".  


MECHANICAL INTEGRITY  

The Hatters Pond Gas Plant has well-established practices and  procedures to maintain  pressure vessels,  piping systems, pressure relief, vent systems, operating controls, pumps, compressors,  and  emergency shutdown  systems  in a safe operating  condition. The basic aspects of this include:
 
1.    Conducting training
2.    Following manufactures written procedures
3.    Performing inspections and tests
4.    Correcting identified deficiencies

These activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process. Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels). Application of various elements of Chevron Operating Management System (OE) program ensures mechanical integrity is maintained on existing and new installations.


HOT WORK PERMIT 

The hot work permit currently being used at the plant meets the Hot Work requirements of PSM/RMP.


MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE  

The Management of Change (MOC) process is used to identify, evaluate, and control hazards in the workplace that may be introduced because of change.  The process establishes the minimum procedures necessary to provide for the safety of personnel and facilities due to these changes or modifications.  The MOC process applies to all work done by Chevron employees or contrac

tors.  Changes to equipment or operations which are not replaced A?in kindA? require appropriate review and approval prior to implementation.  This review is necessary to ensure the safety of personnel and the integrity of the facilities.  The established procedure should communicate changes or modifications to effected employees or contractors.
INCIDENT INVESTIGATION 

Chevron is committed to investigating all incidents regardless of severity to prevent recurrence and ensure employee safety.  Incidents are defined as undesired events that resulted in harm to people, damage to the environment, damage to the property, or loss to process and/or the environment.  These include but are not limited to personal injuries, unplanned product releases, equipment malfunction, spills, fires, etc.  Near-misses are defined as undesired events which, under slightly different circumstances, could have resulted in harm to people, significant damage to property, or loss to process and/or the environment. Employees and contractors are required to report all incidents regardless of their severity immediately to their supervisor or HES representative as soon as feasibly possible. After an interview with the injured party is established, a SiteSafe Incident report is completed with complete details of the incident.  An investigation starts as soon as possible to determine the cause of the incident.  The findings and recommendations are addressed promptly.  The report is reviewed with affected personnel and retained on file for five (5) years.


EMERGENCY PLANNING AND RESPONSE 

The Hatters Pond Gas Plant maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The procedures address all  aspects  of emergency response, including

proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation  plans and  accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response  agencies and  the  public  if a release occurs,  and  post incident cleanup requirements. In addition, the plant has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to the gas plant process or other Hatters Pond Gas Plant facilities.


Emergency Planning and Response is the action plan for personnel to follow during an emergency.  At Hatters Pond Gas Plant, Emergency Planning and Response includes:

    A?    Procedures for handling small releases
    A?    Staging areas at the plant
    A?    Emergency equipment available at the plant    
    A?    Emergency medical transportation
    A?    Spill Control and Countermeasure Plan (SPCC)
    A?    Contingency plan





COMPLIANCE AUDITS 

Every three (3) years, a compliance audit on PSM/RMP is conducted. Documentation of audit findings and solutions and the correction of those findings is required by PSM/RMP. The findings are tracked until resolved.

(*)          PSM/RMP compliance date 8/23/2008




RELEASE PREVENTION

The processes at the Hatters Pond Gas Plant have hazards that must be managed for continued safe operation. Following is a description of existing safety features applicable to prevention of accidental releases of regulated substances in the facility. Collectively, these safety features help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human error.
A?    Hydrocarbon/hydrogen sulfide detectors with audible and visual alarms
A?    Process relief valves that discharge into the plant flare system
A?    Automated & manual valves to permi

t isolation of  the process
A?    Plant/compressor station emergency shutdowns
A?    Fire and smoke detection system with audible and visual alarms
A?    Curbing and/or diking to contain liquid releases 
A?    Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system


RELEASE MITIGATION

A?    Fire extinguishing equipment
A?    Personnel trained in emergency action
A?    PPE 


FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no releases of regulated substances that resulted in onsite or offsite effects during the past 5 years (2005-2009). We investigate accidents/incidents to determine ways to prevent similar accidents/incidents from recurring.
